subject: Re: Is Junit-based testing REALLY possible for commercial software development ?

messageBody:
Thanks for your input and please read my comments and further
questions inline.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "j0hlrogge" <j0hlrogge@...> wrote:
> Today I would actually think twice if I knew that a comercial product
> was not properly unit-tested before buying it, I would not trust its
> quality since I have seen the difference in my code and other peoples
> code when changing towards TDD.


[Frank] That's a very interesitng point. If this becomes a trend in
the market, it would be much easier to convince managers that we
should embrace Unit Testing as early as possible. ;)

>
> The development was no picknick, TDD is not a silver bullet and you
> make mistakes while you learn how to master it. This application was
> no exception.
> After we went live only 2 bugs have ever been discovered and none of
> them serious. The other application had more than 100 reported bugs of
> different levels chriticality the first week.
>
> I attribute this difference mainly to the fact that we had unit-tests
> and the others didn't (It would be tempting to think that we were
> simply that much better and smarter but realistically: our choice of
> enginering approach was better in this case). It is also interesting
> to note that we did not need more time to finish our application than
> the other team did, I think that this is bvecause they spent more time
> in word than we did and we spent more time in code than they did,
> relying more on our testcases to drive the design and acting on the
> feedback we got from our tests. In fact our server side components
> were live 1 week before theirs.

[Frank] That is pretty impressive and just what I am looking forward
to see, which makes me more confident to embrance JUnit-based testing.

>
> Do I think unit testing takes more time? Yes and no:
>
> Yes - because there is more code to write, and in the beginning there
> is a learning curve. I would say that you would experience a drop in
> productivity the first couple of months until you get the "hang of it"
> TDD is a new way of thinking but it is worth learning. I think TDD is
> almost as big of a change as it is to change from procvedural oriented
> thinking to OO thinking, you never stop learning and it will take you
> years to master it (although you will get benefits from it much earlier)


[Frank] That happens to be my guess. However, I am not sure how much
extra effort would be involved so far.

> No - because you tend to write less "unused code" simply because
> having to have a test for every line of code you write makes you
> reluctant to do "might be good if I want to do this in the future"
> kind of design stunts. This also comes from the knowledge that
> changing the code to support those "might be good to haves" is
> straight forward, if you have the tests, when they change from "might
> be good" to "are necesary".
> Less "might be good to haves" alsoe leaves less production code to
> maintain wich saves some effort, I don't remember who said that he
> "would rather have his developers surf the web than adding code that
> did not immediately provide any value". An interesting thought.
>

[Frank] This is pretty impressive and I did not think about thing like
this.



> No - Because your design, with TDD, tends to be simpler, more to the
> point and better when you drive it with tests (when you learn how to
> do that, before that you will just have very complicated tests and the
> same design).
> Yes - Because if you have not been doing test-driven development so
> far your design will likely be hard to test until you remedy that. To
> fix that is time well spent since a testable design is usually an
> extendable one and when you have your tests you will see that you can
> add new features faster than you thought were possible. But
> productivity will no doubt drop until you have spent some time
> refactoring for testability (and fixing what you break/try to prevent
> to break stuff while doing that since you have no tests at the moment)

[Frank] Seems you assume Unit Testing natually means TDD. However, I
saw some others guys said although it is best to have Unit Testing in
TDD process, it is not a mandatary. Do you think Unit Testing can
still give us lots of benefits even if we do not follow Agile
methodology like XP, or even not follow TDD ?


> I am not saing that your design is bad, I'm saying that it is unlikely
> to be very good for testing if that has not been a design-goal (from
> my experience)
>
> About testing web-based applications and the effectiveness of unit
> tests I would say that JUnit is equally appropriate for web, but, with
> JUnit you test one class at the time (if you do it interaction based)
> or several classes from one class at the time (if you are doing
> statebased testing).

[Frank] Not quite follow you here. I guess when you mentioned "with
JUnit you test one class at the time (if you do it interaction
based)", what you meant is to test the interaction between objects by
using "mock objects", right ?

> In order to find bugs in your HTML etc you need
> system tests and other tools (or add ons) to test that.

[Frank] What exact "other tools" are you talking about here ? like
HttpUnit, HtmlUnit, Canoo and etc ?


> (The example I
> gave you was a unit-tested serverside with a manually tested
> presentation layer). What you want to do though is to put as little
> business logic in your presentation layer as you can (that is put no
> businesslogic there) so that all your businesslogic can be unit
> tested. When you have that you find a lot fewer bugs in your
> presentation-layer.

>
> More and more tools are available testing web apps, I heard about but
> never tried "selenium" try that one. And I also recomend looking at
> www.testdriven.com to see if you can find anything that suits you. But
> regardless of wether you test the generated html or not you can still
> rely on the fact that what is beneath your presentation-layer works.


[Frank] You are telling me that in this example project, you tested
only the biz layer code and did not do any automatic testing against
the "html/jsp", right ?


> Sorry for the blah, blah response I easilly get caught up in these
> things :) I hope you could distill something useful from this massive
> amount of text :)
>

[Frank] Thanks a lot for your great patience to spend so much time to
share your experience to me. I think I learned a lot from you
comments. This really helps. :)

Cheers,
- Frank
